org.chronos.chronodb.internal.api

Interface Period

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.lang.Comparable<Period>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    PeriodImpl

    public interface Period
extends java.lang.Comparable<Period>
    A Period is a range (or interval) of timestamps.

    This interface represents a generic, general purpose Period. The period is defined by two Long values:

    • The lower bound (see: getLowerBound()). This value is always included in the period.
    • The upper bound (see: getUpperBound()). This value is always excluded from the period.
    In mathematical notation, the period P is therefore defined as: 
         P := [lower;upper[
    Containment of a given timestamp in a given period can be determined via contains(long). Note that this class also implements Comparable, by comparing the lower bounds of any two periods.

    A period can also be empty, in which case isEmpty() returns true. In an empty period, contains(long) will always return false. The bounds of an empty period can be arbitrary, but the lower bound must be at least as large as the upper bound, and both bounds must refer to non-negative values.

    • Method Detail

      • empty

        static Period empty()
        Returns an empty period.

        An empty period is a period where contains(long) always returns false, and the getLowerBound() is greater than or equal to getUpperBound(). In this implementation, getLowerBound() and getUpperBound() both return zero.

        Returns:
        The empty period. Never null.

      • eternal

        static Period eternal()
        Returns the "eternal" period, i.e. the period that contains all non-negative timestamps.
        Returns:
        The eternal period. Never null.

      • createRange

        static Period createRange(long lowerBoundInclusive,
                          long upperBoundExclusive)
        Creates a period that contains a range of timestamps.

        This method can not be used to create empty periods. Please use empty() instead.

        Parameters:
        lowerBoundInclusive - The lower bound timestamp to be included in the new period. Must not be negative. Must be strictly smaller than upperBoundExclusive.
        upperBoundExclusive - The upper bound timestamp to be exclused from the period. Must not be negative. Must be strictly larger than lowerBoundInclusive.
        Returns:
        A new period with the given range of timestamps.

      • createOpenEndedRange

        static Period createOpenEndedRange(long lowerBound)
        Creates a new Period that starts at the given lower bound (inclusive) and is open-ended.

        In other words, contains(long) will always return true for all timestamps greater than or equal to the given one.

        Calling getUpperBound() on the resulting period will return Long.MAX_VALUE.

        Parameters:
        lowerBound - The lower bound to use for the new range period. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        A period that starts at the given lower bound (inclusive) and is open-ended.

      • createPoint

        static Period createPoint(long timestamp)
        Creates a new Period that contains only one point in time, which is the given timestamp.

        In other words, contains(long) will always return false for all timestamps, except for the given one.

        The lower bound of the period will be set to the given timestamp (as it is inclusive), the upper bound will be set to the given timestamp + 1 (exclusive).

        Parameters:
        timestamp - The timestamp which should be contained in the resulting period. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        A period that contains only the given timestamp. Never null.

      • getLowerBound

        long getLowerBound()
        Returns the timestamp that represents the lower bound of this period.

        The lower bound is always included in a period. Therefore calling: 

         period.contains(period.getLowerBound())
        ... always returns true, unless the period is empty.

        The lower bound timestamp is always a value greater than or equal to zero. In all non-empty periods, the lower bound is strictly smaller than the upper bound.

        Returns:
        The timestamp that represents the lower bound.

      • getUpperBound

        long getUpperBound()
        Returns the timestamp that represents the upper bound of this period.

        The upper bound is always excluded from a period. Therefore calling: 

         period.contains(period.getUpperBound())
        ... always returns false.

        The upper bound is a always a value greater than or equal to zero. In all non-empty periods, the upper bound is strictly larger than the lower bound.

        Returns:
        The timestamp that represents the upper bound.

      • contains

        default boolean contains(long timestamp)
        Checks if the given timestamp is contained in (i.e. part of) this period.

        A timestamp is contained in a period if the following condition holds: 

         p.lowerBound <= timestamp < p.upperBound

        This method always returns false (regardless of the argument) if this period is empty.

        Parameters:
        timestamp - The timestamp to check. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        true if the given timestamp is contained in this period, otherwise false.

      • isEmpty

        default boolean isEmpty()
        Checks if this period is empty or not.

        A period p is empty if and only if there is no valid timestamp t for which 

         p.contains(t)
        returns true. In empty periods, getLowerBound() always returns a value that is greater than or equal to the value returned by getUpperBound().
        Returns:
        true if this period is empty, otherwise false.

      • overlaps

        default boolean overlaps(Period other)
        Checks if there is an overlap between this period and the given period.

        Two periods P1 and P2 overlap each other, if there is at least one timestamp t where 

         P1.contains(t) && P2.contains(t)
        ... returns true. In other words, two periods overlap if there is at least one timestamp which is contained in both periods.

        If either this period or the other period is empty, this method will always return false.

        Parameters:
        other - The period to check for an overlap with. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        true if there is an overlap between this and the other period, otherwise false.

      • contains

        default boolean contains(Period other)
        Checks if this period fully contains the other period.

        A period P1 contains a period P2 if, for all timestamps t in P2 

         P1.contains(t)
        ... returns true. In other words, a period is contained in another period if all timestamps from the first period are also contained in the second period.

        If either this period or the other period is empty, this method returns false.

        Parameters:
        other - The other period to check if it is contained in this period. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        true if this period contains the other period, otherwise false.

      • isAdjacentTo

        default boolean isAdjacentTo(Period other)
        Checks if this period is adjacent to the other period.

        A period P1 is adjacent to another period P2 if: 

         P1.upperBound == P2.lowerBound || P1.lowerBound == P2.upperBound
        In other words, two periods are adjacent to each other if there is no timestamp that is between them, but not part of either one of them.

        Note that overlapping periods are never adjacent to each other.

        If either this period or the other period is empty, this method returns false.

        Parameters:
        other - The other period to check adjacency against. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        true if this period is adjacent to the other period, otherwise false.

      • isBefore

        default boolean isBefore(Period other)
        Checks if this period starts before the other period.

        A period P1 is before another period P2 if and only if: 

         P1.lowerBound < P2.lowerBound
        Note that there is no restriction on the upper bounds. Therefore, partially overlapping periods can also be in an "is before" relation with each other.

        If either this period or the other period is empty, this method returns false.

        Parameters:
        other - The other period to check the "is before" relation against. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        true if this period is before the other period, otherwise false.
        See Also:
        isAfter(Period), isStrictlyBefore(Period), isStrictlyAfter(Period)

      • isBefore

        default boolean isBefore(long timestamp)
        Checks if this period starts before the given timestamp (and does not include it). A period P is before a timestamp T if and only if: 
         P.upperBound <= T

        If this period is empty, this method returns false.

        Parameters:
        timestamp - The timestamp to check the "is before" relation against. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        true if this period is before the given timestamp, otherwise false.

      • isAfter

        default boolean isAfter(Period other)
        Checks if this period starts after the other period.

        A period P1 is after another period P2 if and only if: 

         P1.lowerBound > P2.lowerBound
        Note that there is no restriction on the upper bounds. Therefore, partially overlapping periods can also be in an "is after" relation with each other.

        If either this period or the other period is empty, this method returns false.

        Parameters:
        other - The other period to check the "is after" relation against. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        true if this period is after the other period, otherwise false.
        See Also:
        isBefore(Period), isStrictlyBefore(Period), isStrictlyAfter(Period)

      • isAfter

        default boolean isAfter(long timestamp)
        Checks if this period starts after the given timestamp. A period P is after a timestamp T if and only if: 
         P.lowerBound > T

        If this period is empty, this method returns false.

        Parameters:
        timestamp - The timestamp to check the "is after" relation against. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        true if this period is after the given timestamp, otherwise false.

      • isStrictlyBefore

        default boolean isStrictlyBefore(Period other)
        Checks if this period starts and ends before the other period starts.

        A period P1 is strictly before another period P2 if and only if: 

         P1.lowerBound < P2.lowerBound && P1.upperBound <= P2.lowerBound

        If either this period or the other period is empty, this method returns false.

        Parameters:
        other - The other period to check the "is strictly before" relation against. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        true if this period is strictly before the other period, otherwise false.
        See Also:
        isBefore(Period), isAfter(Period), isStrictlyAfter(Period)

      • isStrictlyAfter

        default boolean isStrictlyAfter(Period other)
        Checks if this period starts after the other period ends.

        A period P1 is strictly after another period P2 if and only if: 

         P1.lowerBound >= P2.upperBound

        If either this period or the other period is empty, this method returns false.

        Parameters:
        other - The other period to check the "is strictly after" relation against. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        true if this period is strictly after the other period, otherwise false.
        See Also:
        isBefore(Period), isAfter(Period), isStrictlyBefore(Period)

      • isOpenEnded

        default boolean isOpenEnded()
        Checks if this period has an open end.

        A period is open-ended if getUpperBound() is equal to Long.MAX_VALUE.

        Note that an empty period is never open-ended. For empty periods, this method always returns false.

        Returns:
        true if this period is open-ended, otherwise false.

      • length

        default long length()
        Returns the length of this period.

        The length of a period is defined as the number of different timestamps which are contained in this period.

        For the empty period, this method always returns zero. For all other periods, a non-negative number is returned.

        Returns:
        The number of different timestamps contained in this period.

      • setUpperBound

        default Period setUpperBound(long newUpperBound)
        Creates a duplicate of this period, replacing the original upper bound with the given upper bound.

        this will not be modified.

        Please note that this method does not allow to create empty ranges, i.e. the new upper bound must always be strictly larger than the lower bound.

        This operation is only allowed on non-empty periods. This method throws an IllegalStateException if the original period is empty.

        Parameters:
        newUpperBound - The new upper bound to use. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        The new period with the given upper bound.

      • compareTo

        default int compareTo(Period other)
        Compares this period to the given period.

        Two periods are compared by comparing the lower bounds. The upper bounds are ignored in the comparison.

        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface java.lang.Comparable<Period>
        Parameters:
        other - The other period to compare this period to
        Returns:
        A value less than, equal to, or larger than zero if this period is less than, equal to, or larger than the other period.
